description: In these episodes we look at the transition of an IT service from a design plan to a live service. We examine closely processes such as Change Management and Release and Deployment Management and we also look at what services are made of in Service Asset & Configuration Management. We look at the concept of early life support and also the value of knowledge in enabling decision making. Like all ITIL shows we also look at critical success factors and key performance indicators and we do some exam prep too!
descriptionMD: ** Look for our partner PassionIT Group's information [HERE](https://itprotv-notes-bucket.s3.amazonaws.com/ITIL_OVERVIEW.zip)  Codes for offers are available to members and in the download in the second episode** In these episodes we look at the transition of an IT service from a design plan to a live service. We examine closely processes such as Change Management and Release and Deployment Management and we also look at what services are made of in Service Asset & Configuration Management. We look at the concept of early life support and also the value of knowledge in enabling decision making. Like all ITIL shows we also look at critical success factors and key performance indicators and we do some exam prep too! For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please [contact PassionIT Group](mailto:info@passionitgroup.com).
name: Accredited ITIL Intermediate - Service Transition
subtitle: Service Transition

episodes.description: In these episodes we look at the transition of an IT service from a design plan to a live service. We examine closely processes such as Change Management and Release and Deployment Management and we also look at what services are made of in Service Asset & Configuration Management. We look at the concept of early life support and also the value of knowledge in enabling decision making. Like all ITIL shows we also look at critical success factors and key performance indicators and we do some exam prep too! For course completion certificates to be submitted for exams, please contact PassionIT Group.
episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL Intermediate
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:06.224
[SOUND] Hi and welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:06.224 --> 00:00:08.174
My name is Jo Peacock, and

3
00:00:08.174 --> 00:00:14.127
I'm going to be taking you through
an introduction to your ITIL Intermediate.

4
00:00:14.127 --> 00:00:18.291
So let's take a look then at our
first slide here, coming up.

5
00:00:18.291 --> 00:00:22.360
And we have our introduction
to our intermediate class, and

6
00:00:22.360 --> 00:00:27.730
exactly what content is going to be found
in this upcoming intermediate class.

7
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:32.340
You will see, what we will cover
is an introduction to the class,

8
00:00:32.340 --> 00:00:37.100
followed by the principles and
the processes of the life cycle phase.

9
00:00:37.100 --> 00:00:40.550
Then we'll take a look organizing for
that life cycle phase,

10
00:00:40.550 --> 00:00:43.500
and also the technology considerations,

11
00:00:43.500 --> 00:00:48.270
especially those that we need when
we're implementing the phase itself.

12
00:00:48.270 --> 00:00:51.880
Then we'll take a look at the challenges
and the critical success factors, and

13
00:00:51.880 --> 00:00:57.140
all of the risks that are associated
with that particular life cycle phase.

14
00:00:57.140 --> 00:01:00.603
And most importantly of course for
you, is that preparation for

15
00:01:00.603 --> 00:01:04.980
the exam that's going to be coming up
when you have completed your class, okay?

16
00:01:05.980 --> 00:01:10.670
So let me take a look now then at how
we're going to approach this particular

17
00:01:10.670 --> 00:01:11.790
intermediate class.

18
00:01:14.250 --> 00:01:17.230
We're going to be doing
some presentation work.

19
00:01:17.230 --> 00:01:22.550
Obviously, you're going to be watching us
on screen, both myself and my colleague.

20
00:01:22.550 --> 00:01:27.110
And we're going to be taking through
the course materials for the class.

21
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:29.910
And then,
there are going to be some discussions and

22
00:01:29.910 --> 00:01:35.530
some exercises that are going to be
based primarily in our chat rooms,

23
00:01:35.530 --> 00:01:38.140
and also in our forums as well.

24
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.530
And we're also available, if you want
to undertake any of the assessments.

25
00:01:42.530 --> 00:01:46.168
Then please feel free to come
back to us via the forums, and

26
00:01:46.168 --> 00:01:49.080
we will be able to help
you out in any way we can.

27
00:01:49.080 --> 00:01:52.808
Also provided in the course material,
which is available for

28
00:01:52.808 --> 00:01:57.120
you to download are mock tests or
exams, if you prefer to use that word.

29
00:01:57.120 --> 00:02:02.720
And we will be conducting a run
through of that mock exam for you.

30
00:02:04.530 --> 00:02:08.621
So where are we then at
ITIL intermediate level?

31
00:02:08.621 --> 00:02:11.873
Well, you'll see in
using Bloom's Taxonomy,

32
00:02:11.873 --> 00:02:14.820
that we are actually at level 4 analyzing.

33
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:18.100
In other words,
we've done at foundation level.

34
00:02:18.100 --> 00:02:20.081
We've done the remembering and

35
00:02:20.081 --> 00:02:23.243
the understanding of those
concepts within ITIL.

36
00:02:23.243 --> 00:02:27.686
And we're actually moving through
applying those concepts to

37
00:02:27.686 --> 00:02:33.090
analyzing those concepts, and
being able to apply the ITIL processes.

38
00:02:33.090 --> 00:02:40.248
And also the concepts at a real-world
level in a real-world situation.

39
00:02:40.248 --> 00:02:42.590
So where does ITIL comes from then?

40
00:02:42.590 --> 00:02:44.849
Well, let me give you
a little bit of a background.

41
00:02:44.849 --> 00:02:47.857
It's actually owned by
a company called Axelos.

42
00:02:47.857 --> 00:02:54.110
And it was first published in
the mid 1980s by the UK government.

43
00:02:54.110 --> 00:03:00.748
And the Office of Government Commerce
owned ITIL for a very, very long time.

44
00:03:00.748 --> 00:03:05.196
And we developed ITIL right
the way back from the 1980s

45
00:03:05.196 --> 00:03:08.828
through it's version two in the 1990's,

46
00:03:08.828 --> 00:03:14.115
mid 1990's to version three,
which was released in 2007.

47
00:03:14.115 --> 00:03:18.848
And then there was an update
to version three in 2011,

48
00:03:18.848 --> 00:03:22.140
which is exactly where we are right now.

49
00:03:22.140 --> 00:03:23.010
It is copyrighted.

50
00:03:23.010 --> 00:03:25.110
It is trademark protected.

51
00:03:25.110 --> 00:03:30.960
It's a framework for managing services,
and as such it is a flexible framework.

52
00:03:30.960 --> 00:03:36.730
A framework that we would expect any
organization to adopt as a framework,

53
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:39.948
but then to adopt it to suit your needs,
okay?

54
00:03:39.948 --> 00:03:44.209
ITIL was born right
the way back in the 1980s,

55
00:03:44.209 --> 00:03:49.180
out of a desire to be able to
demonstrate value for money and

56
00:03:49.180 --> 00:03:54.070
efficiency for
the use of taxpayers money within the UK.

57
00:03:54.070 --> 00:03:58.175
Way back in the 1980s,
these things started appearing on desk.

58
00:03:58.175 --> 00:04:03.800
And quite frankly, we didn't know
how to manage these in an unbiased,

59
00:04:03.800 --> 00:04:08.129
in an impartial, and
an efficient and effective way.

60
00:04:08.129 --> 00:04:10.420
And thus ITIL was born.

61
00:04:10.420 --> 00:04:15.521
And ITIL was born from a group of industry
experts that went out into the big wide

62
00:04:15.521 --> 00:04:21.397
world, and analyzed various organizations
from a various different industry sectors,

63
00:04:21.397 --> 00:04:27.062
not just government, but we're talking
finance, we're talking retail, and etc.

64
00:04:27.062 --> 00:04:31.230
And they came back with
a set of best practices.

65
00:04:31.230 --> 00:04:38.109
Best practices that they observed in the
real world for managing our IT services.

66
00:04:38.109 --> 00:04:39.950
And thus, we have ITIL.

67
00:04:39.950 --> 00:04:43.520
And as I've already said,
we've had subsequent revisions.

68
00:04:43.520 --> 00:04:46.063
And now, we're up to version three 2011.

69
00:04:46.063 --> 00:04:51.071
So we work on the understanding that,

70
00:04:51.071 --> 00:04:56.240
we have a life to every single service.

71
00:04:57.500 --> 00:05:00.960
And we start off with a concept and
service strategy, and

72
00:05:00.960 --> 00:05:05.080
then we take that concept and
we design it.

73
00:05:05.080 --> 00:05:09.731
And then we develop it, and
we deploy it as a service into a live

74
00:05:09.731 --> 00:05:14.573
environment which is where we operate and
where we maintain it.

75
00:05:14.573 --> 00:05:19.003
And we continually seek to
ensure that we are aligned with

76
00:05:19.003 --> 00:05:21.969
the needs of the organization in CSI.

77
00:05:24.692 --> 00:05:27.130
So you're attending this class,

78
00:05:27.130 --> 00:05:33.027
because you probably want to achieve
an ITIL intermediate qualification, okay?

79
00:05:34.180 --> 00:05:37.920
So you can see that if we were
to start off right at the very,

80
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:40.292
very top, you'll see where I am.

81
00:05:40.292 --> 00:05:46.560
I am an accredited ITIL trainer working
with an accredited training organization.

82
00:05:46.560 --> 00:05:51.610
I'm also an accredited examiner and
proctor or invigilator for

83
00:05:51.610 --> 00:05:57.020
these exams,and work very, very closely
with the official ITIL accreditor and

84
00:05:57.020 --> 00:06:00.560
also Axelos who owns the ITIL copyright.

85
00:06:02.100 --> 00:06:07.080
Now in terms of ITIL, where can you
go with your qualification level?

86
00:06:07.080 --> 00:06:08.859
Well, we start off with ITIL foundation.

87
00:06:08.859 --> 00:06:13.908
And ITIL foundation is a,
would traditionally be a three day

88
00:06:13.908 --> 00:06:19.750
classroom experience where we learn
the foundations of ITIL, okay?

89
00:06:19.750 --> 00:06:23.692
And we learned all the terminology and all
of the definitions to that terminology.

90
00:06:23.692 --> 00:06:28.900
There's roughly around about 75 that we
learn within the ITIL foundation class.

91
00:06:28.900 --> 00:06:34.440
And then as we move through, we can either
take an ITIL practitioner class, which can

92
00:06:34.440 --> 00:06:39.976
be taken at any point in time throughout
the progression of your career within

93
00:06:39.976 --> 00:06:46.220
ITIL, because ITIL practitioner focuses
on the implementation of ITIL, okay?

94
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:50.210
Whereas, if we take a look at the more
advanced intermediate classes,

95
00:06:50.210 --> 00:06:55.040
you are at this moment
in a life cycle module.

96
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:59.720
And those life cycle modules consist
of service strategies, service design,

97
00:06:59.720 --> 00:07:04.470
service transition, service operation,
and continual service improvement.

98
00:07:04.470 --> 00:07:07.680
And that’s where we focus on those
life cycles that we've just looked at

99
00:07:07.680 --> 00:07:09.330
previously.

100
00:07:09.330 --> 00:07:14.268
Okay, and on the right-hand side
then we have our capability modules.

101
00:07:14.268 --> 00:07:22.461
And these capability modules really focus
on specific areas within ITIL such as RCV,

102
00:07:22.461 --> 00:07:27.372
which focuses on release control and
validation.

103
00:07:27.372 --> 00:07:30.897
And these classes,
you will notice that every single one

104
00:07:30.897 --> 00:07:34.430
of this classes has got
a score right beside each one.

105
00:07:34.430 --> 00:07:38.080
So we've got a number two for
ITIL foundation and we've got a three for

106
00:07:38.080 --> 00:07:44.660
life cycle modules, and we've got
a four for our capability modules.

107
00:07:44.660 --> 00:07:50.700
Now what we need to do is ensure
that we have achieved a minimum

108
00:07:50.700 --> 00:07:57.935
of 15 credits at both either life cycle or
capability module level.

109
00:07:57.935 --> 00:08:03.855
In order to be able to qualify to see
the managing across the life cycle class,

110
00:08:03.855 --> 00:08:08.665
and the full subsequently,
the test that goes among with that class.

111
00:08:08.665 --> 00:08:11.995
So we need to take two
from the ITIL foundation.

112
00:08:11.995 --> 00:08:15.065
That's a prerequisite,
we have to do the foundation and

113
00:08:15.065 --> 00:08:19.500
then we need to add in another
15 scores from either,

114
00:08:19.500 --> 00:08:24.090
as I've said, the life cycle or capability
stream, now you can interchange.

115
00:08:24.090 --> 00:08:29.100
You can mix and match, you do not have
to stick to one stream or the other.

116
00:08:29.100 --> 00:08:33.215
Once you've gotten that 17 in total scores

117
00:08:33.215 --> 00:08:37.165
that are needed to be able to sit
managing across the life cycle.

118
00:08:37.165 --> 00:08:41.345
Your perfectly able to sit
that life cycle class and

119
00:08:41.345 --> 00:08:43.845
to be able to take that test afterwards.

120
00:08:43.845 --> 00:08:48.341
And as soon as you've taken that test,
you will be awarded those five

121
00:08:48.341 --> 00:08:52.307
credits which will mean that
you have achieved ITIL expert.

122
00:08:52.307 --> 00:08:57.442
Now ITIL expert is allocated as soon
as you have pass the management

123
00:08:57.442 --> 00:09:02.510
across the lifecycle test,
and have achieved 22 credits.

124
00:09:02.510 --> 00:09:07.272
Both of those must happen in order for
you to achieve Itil expert.

125
00:09:07.272 --> 00:09:10.657
Now we have the ITIL master qualification,
and

126
00:09:10.657 --> 00:09:14.630
the ITIL master is
a completely different beast.

127
00:09:14.630 --> 00:09:19.220
The ITIL master is a two
year qualification.

128
00:09:19.220 --> 00:09:24.839
And during that two years,
you will be expected to submit various

129
00:09:24.839 --> 00:09:31.191
white papers on specific topics within
the ITIL qualifications scheme.

130
00:09:31.191 --> 00:09:35.598
So this could be topics on,
activities within ITIL.

131
00:09:35.598 --> 00:09:38.830
This could be talked with
some processes within ITIL.

132
00:09:38.830 --> 00:09:43.581
This could be topics on implementation
of various aspects of ITIL.

133
00:09:43.581 --> 00:09:47.082
But you will be require to sit
a number of white papers or

134
00:09:47.082 --> 00:09:51.410
submit a number of white papers
over the period of two years.

135
00:09:51.410 --> 00:09:56.520
At the end of those two years,
once you have submitted the prerequisite

136
00:09:56.520 --> 00:10:01.260
white papers, then you will be
asked to attend a panel interview.

137
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:04.630
And during that panel interview
you will be assessed.

138
00:10:04.630 --> 00:10:06.760
Not only on your white papers,

139
00:10:06.760 --> 00:10:11.880
but also on your experience within
the IT service management arena.

140
00:10:11.880 --> 00:10:13.890
And at the end of that paneling to view,

141
00:10:13.890 --> 00:10:18.630
then if successful, you will be
awarded the status of ITIL Master.

142
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:21.700
So the qualification scheme,

143
00:10:21.700 --> 00:10:25.340
I'm going to take this back
now to Bloom's taxonomy then.

144
00:10:25.340 --> 00:10:29.360
And just very, very quickly, look at
the fact that an ITIL foundation, and

145
00:10:29.360 --> 00:10:32.450
I know that I've already covered
this in a previous slide.

146
00:10:32.450 --> 00:10:36.700
We just looked at understanding
the terminology and

147
00:10:36.700 --> 00:10:39.150
the concepts of ITIL foundation.

148
00:10:39.150 --> 00:10:41.273
And then in the lifecycle modules,

149
00:10:41.273 --> 00:10:45.679
we're looking at implementing those
processes contained within ITIL.

150
00:10:45.679 --> 00:10:50.937
And in capability, we're looking at
actually undertaking those processes and

151
00:10:50.937 --> 00:10:52.802
managing those processes.

152
00:10:52.802 --> 00:10:55.330
Who is managing across the life cycle?

153
00:10:55.330 --> 00:10:57.890
This is for senior management.

154
00:10:57.890 --> 00:11:02.190
This is at CIO level and
at senior management level, and

155
00:11:02.190 --> 00:11:05.905
in as we like to abbreviate it to.

156
00:11:05.905 --> 00:11:10.165
Your concern with leading
IT service management.

157
00:11:10.165 --> 00:11:14.818
So I mentioned, right,
at the very beginning of all of this,

158
00:11:14.818 --> 00:11:20.466
that we had a test to go along with every
single lifecycle face and there is.

159
00:11:20.466 --> 00:11:25.573
And we will conducting this session
to go all over this particular test,

160
00:11:25.573 --> 00:11:30.345
or at least a sample of this test
just to give you some preparation for

161
00:11:30.345 --> 00:11:32.960
the actual test itself.

162
00:11:32.960 --> 00:11:37.600
So your test is conducted online,
it's conducted virtually.

163
00:11:39.160 --> 00:11:44.120
It is an eight multiple
choice question test, okay?

164
00:11:44.120 --> 00:11:46.390
It's complex multiple choice.

165
00:11:46.390 --> 00:11:49.440
You get an hour and a half for
this particular test, and

166
00:11:49.440 --> 00:11:53.840
with every single question,
you will be given a scenario and

167
00:11:53.840 --> 00:11:58.270
then you will be given
four possible options,

168
00:11:58.270 --> 00:12:04.660
four possible answers for the question
that is posed along with that scenario.

169
00:12:04.660 --> 00:12:07.920
You get five points for
the best fit answer.

170
00:12:07.920 --> 00:12:09.730
Now mentions out there are the most.

171
00:12:09.730 --> 00:12:14.667
I always call it the best fit,
because every single question asks what

172
00:12:14.667 --> 00:12:19.030
is the best answer given the scenario and
given the question?

173
00:12:19.030 --> 00:12:25.168
Don't be alarmed if you don't see
an answer that you think is 100% correct,

174
00:12:25.168 --> 00:12:29.152
because the question is asking you for
the best fit.

175
00:12:29.152 --> 00:12:32.990
And for that best fit,
you're gonna get five points.

176
00:12:32.990 --> 00:12:35.732
For the next best fit,
you're gonna get three.

177
00:12:35.732 --> 00:12:40.204
For the next one, which we've
considered to be the least correct,

178
00:12:40.204 --> 00:12:41.783
you're gonna get one.

179
00:12:41.783 --> 00:12:45.050
And for the next one,
you're gonna get a zero.

180
00:12:45.050 --> 00:12:50.110
Now it mentions up on that slide there
that the next one is zero marks for

181
00:12:50.110 --> 00:12:51.020
incorrect.

182
00:12:51.020 --> 00:12:56.490
We like to call that in the industry us
in the know we call that the distractor.

183
00:12:56.490 --> 00:13:00.600
And we call it the distractor for
a reason, cuz it distracts.

184
00:13:00.600 --> 00:13:05.215
And quite often what you will find is with
your distractor a lot of the words and

185
00:13:05.215 --> 00:13:08.907
the terminology that are taken
straight out of the ITIL book,

186
00:13:08.907 --> 00:13:13.309
straight out of the publications, and
our input into that zero pointed.

187
00:13:13.309 --> 00:13:17.122
Because it's there to distract,
and it sounds great.

188
00:13:17.122 --> 00:13:21.825
But more often than not,
that distractor has no

189
00:13:21.825 --> 00:13:26.600
relevance to the scenario or
to the question.

190
00:13:26.600 --> 00:13:29.390
So you have to be incredibly
careful with that.

191
00:13:29.390 --> 00:13:31.480
It's so easy to be distracted.

192
00:13:32.800 --> 00:13:38.270
You have to get 28 out of a possible
40 in order to be able to pass,

193
00:13:38.270 --> 00:13:42.660
and achieve accreditation at
any lifecycle test, okay?

194
00:13:44.540 --> 00:13:48.960
If English is not your first language, you
are allowed a paper dictionary, but you

195
00:13:48.960 --> 00:13:55.650
will be ask to show that to the proctor
at that time that you take the test.

196
00:13:55.650 --> 00:14:02.410
And as I've already said, you have to
have an ITIL foundation in version 3 or

197
00:14:02.410 --> 00:14:09.459
version 3 2011, or an ITIL version
2 foundation bridge to version 3.

198
00:14:11.060 --> 00:14:12.940
I will be very, very honest with you.

199
00:14:12.940 --> 00:14:17.500
There are not that many people that
have attained the version 2 to

200
00:14:17.500 --> 00:14:22.520
version 3 bridge, and
most people will have the version 3 or

201
00:14:22.520 --> 00:14:25.800
2011, ITIL foundation certificate.

202
00:14:27.540 --> 00:14:31.730
You will be required to
upload that certificate to

203
00:14:31.730 --> 00:14:36.510
the examining board prior to
CT in your lifecycle test.

204
00:14:36.510 --> 00:14:38.430
So be prepared with that.

205
00:14:38.430 --> 00:14:42.590
You will need to have it to hand and
save as a PDF as well.

206
00:14:44.250 --> 00:14:50.160
So when we come to the end of
every single life cycle class,

207
00:14:50.160 --> 00:14:53.420
we will be going over, and
this one's no exception.

208
00:14:53.420 --> 00:14:56.410
We'll be going over a sample test for you.

209
00:14:56.410 --> 00:14:59.670
And during that sample test,
I'll be giving you lots of hints and

210
00:14:59.670 --> 00:15:04.150
tips on how to select that
best fit possible answer.

211
00:15:04.150 --> 00:15:08.300
And also, how to ensure that you read
the full question, how to relax and

212
00:15:08.300 --> 00:15:12.740
to make sure that you approach
it with an open mind.

213
00:15:12.740 --> 00:15:16.100
But you consider relevance
in every single answer.

214
00:15:17.590 --> 00:15:22.321
Ultimately, we wanna get you past
the test just as much as you want

215
00:15:22.321 --> 00:15:24.738
to achieve that accreditation.

216
00:15:24.738 --> 00:15:30.473
So just to sum up what we will be
doing over the next few shows,

217
00:15:30.473 --> 00:15:37.231
is encouraging you to take your ITIL
lifecycle intermediate classes.

218
00:15:37.231 --> 00:15:41.685
And feel free to join us in the forums for
any questions that you may have.

219
00:15:41.685 --> 00:15:45.954
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo begin the foundation refresher. Jo reviews the key aspects of ITIL foundation by describing the 5 core volume service lifecycles: service strategy, service design, service transition, service operation, and continual service improvement. She also defines what ITIL means by a Service and Service Management. Also the key terms that define value: Utility and Warranty by Jo.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo continue with the foundation refresher. Jo reviews asset, resource, capabilities and processes from the ITIL perspective. She emphasizes the process model and roles associated with processes. Lastly, she describes the accountability that belongs to the service owner as well.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee explain the importance of  ensuring  any modifications to the IT environment affecting new, modified or retiring services meet the expectations of the business, customers and users.
episodes.title: Objectives and Principles

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee introduce a high-level view of the communications and management activities which support service transition. They discuss effective ways to manage communications, commitment and more.  Tune in to learn the emotional cycle and understand how to motivate.
episodes.title: Managing People Through Transitions

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo cover the aspects of organizational roles and responsibilities, along with how to plan and implement organizational change. In addition, they also explain methods, practices and techniques relating to assessing organizational readiness for, monitoring progress of,  and organizational change.
episodes.title: Managing People Through Transitions Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Jo discuss how to manage Stakeholders. JO explains the importance of Stakeholder management strategy, changes in stakeholder commitment and even shares tools such as a Stakeholder map to help perform analysis.
episodes.title: Managing People Through Transitions Part 3

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee take a look at how to streamline a process through the use of process models. They encourage the use of process models to facilitate efficient and effective processes that are appealing and not perceived as bureaucratic.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Transition Planning and Support

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee take a look at how to streamline a process through the use of process models. They encourage the use of process models to facilitate efficient and effective processes that are appealing and not perceived as bureaucratic.
episodes.title: Process Models

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and JO define Change  Management as a way to control the lifecycle of all changes whilst enabling beneficial changes to be made with minimum disruption to IT Services. Jo explains the numerous ways it should add value to a business and not add add layers of complexity or bureaucracy.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Change Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo continue to discuss Change Management. Jo explains how it adds value to the business, characterizes qualities of poor Change Management, and more. She also shows the differences between normal, standard and emergency changes. Tune in for more!
episodes.title: ST Process - Change Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo continue to discuss Change Management. Jo identifies inputs such as policies and strategies, RFCs, and change proposals. She them compares those inputs to what an expected output looks like.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Change Management Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo explain the purpose of Configuration Management and how it ensures  the assets required to deliver services are properly controlled, that accurate and reliable information about those assets is available when and where required and includes details of how the assets have been configured and the relationships between them.
episodes.title: ST Processes - SACM

episodes.description: In this episode, Jo and Cherokee continue to discuss SACM. Specifically, Jo describes the breakdown of configuration management systems and the including the logical layers of the Configuration Management System (CMS). In addition to internal structure Jo explains the integration of the Definitive Media Library (DMS), and the Configuration Management Data Base(s) (CMDB).
episodes.title: ST Processes - SACM Part 2

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee explain how Change Evaluation provides a consistent and standardized means of determining the performance of a service change in the context of likely impacts on business outcomes and on existing services and infrastructure.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Change Evaluation

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee explain how to plan and implement a structured validation and test process in addition to explaining the significance to provide an expected quality assurance. Jo also covers how to identify, assess and address issues throughout Service Transition.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Service Validation and Testing

episodes.description: In this show Cherokee and Jo continue talking about service validation and testing. Jo reminds us how how this concept will not be a one size fits all as it greatly depends on what we are testing and how we are testing it. They discuss examples of KPIs to help determine various CSFs. Tune in for all this and more!
episodes.title: ST Processes - Service Validation, Testing Pt. 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo outline how to plan, schedule and control the build They also explain how to manage test and deployment of releases in addition to delivering new functionality required by the business while protecting the integrity of existing services.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Release and Deployment Mgmt

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee continue to discuss Release and Deployment Management . Jo explains the differences between a release process trigger versus a deployment trigger. They also examine how those triggers interface with the four phases of Release and Deployment Management. Inputs, outputs and more are covered as well!
episodes.title: ST Processes - Release and Deployment Mgmt Pt.2

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo foster ideas on how to share perspectives, ideas, experience and information. They also stress the need to  ensure these  ideas are available to enable informed decisions; and to reduce the need to rediscover knowledge. Jo encourages the idea idea of Service Knowledge Management System (SKMS)  as a logical way to interrogate data and the relationships between the configuration items thus providing knowledge and facts to help execute informed decisions.
episodes.title: ST Processes - Knowledge Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Jo cover technology considerations for service transition. Technology’s role in service transition is explored, as well as how it should be “designed in”. They also share the mechanisms for maintaining and maximizing benefit from the technology. A range of tools are reviewed from enterprise-wide tools through to more specific ITSM technology and support tools.
episodes.title: Technology Considerations

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee use the CSI approach to implement Service Transition. Jo walks through the various stages involved and highlights key activities in the introduction of service transition.
episodes.title: Implementing Service Transition

episodes.description: In this show, Jo and Cherokee cover the challenges and critical success factors  critical success factors(CSF) facing service transition. They also explain how risk mitigation contributes to service transition.
episodes.title: Challenges, CSFs and Risks

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Jo review some of the different techniques and details when sitting for your ITIL Intermediate exam. They recommend downloading the sample paper for review. Jo reviews the details on scoring of the exam. She also has solid exam advice for delegates preparing for an exam.
episodes.title: Exam Review Introduciton

episodes.description: ITIL Intermediate Service Transition exam review
episodes.title: Exam Review

episodes.description: ITIL Intermediate Service Transition exam review
episodes.title: Exam Review Part 2
